EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

PPC - Paramount Refinery is located at 14700 Downey Avenue, Paramount, California. The Refinery occupies approximately 63 acres of land located in the city of Paramount in Southern California. The site is bordered on the north by Contreras Street, on the south by Somerset Boulevard and Southern Pacific Railroad track, on the east by Lakewood Boulevard and on the west by Downey Avenue. On the north side of the refinery, a trailer park, a shopping center, Wirtz Elementary School and single-family houses are located. On the west side, Paramount High School and a housing development are located. On the east side, there are single-family homes and mobile home development.  Across the railroad tracks on the south side is an apartment complex. 



The primary business of the Paramount Refinery is the processing of local crude oils to finished hydrocarbon products, primarily asphalts for road construction and roofing materials, as well as reformulated gasoline and ultra low sulfur diesel (ULSD).  The present rated capacity of the refinery is 55 KBPD of crude.



The facility has developed a risk management program to address the EPA RMP requirements (40 CFR Part 68).  PPC - Paramount Refinery is diligent in the handling of all chemicals and is dedicated to the safety of its employees and the neighboring community.  The PPC - Paramount Refinery staff is trained and utilizes equipment to monitor the facility and provide safeguards, during the petroleum refining process.



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION POLICIES

PPC - Paramount Refinery has a long standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as personnel training and consideration of safety in the design, operation, and maintenance of the covered processes.  PPC - Paramount Refinery policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances. 



STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED S

UBSTANCE

Paramount processes crude oil and hence handles all the hydrocarbons that comprise crude oil.  In addition, there are hazardous substances that are utilized in or generated by the process. 

Aqueous Ammonia (19%), Hydrogen sulfide and Sulfur dioxide are also present in the refinery.  However, the threshold quantity of these materials is not exceeded in any process.

Risk Considerations

Although petroleum refining has inherent potential risks, and worst-case release scenarios can potentially reach the community; PPC - Paramount Refinery has recognized these potential risks and structured its safety programs to make the worst case type of event non-credible.  

In addition to the use of conservative analysis assumptions that over-predict the effects of a potential release, other characteristics of the facility and site serve to minimize the potential risks associated with a flammable hydrocar

bon release:

?    The system has alarms and interlocks to minimize the potential for operating outside the normal parameters

?    The system undergoes periodic preventive maintenance to reduce the likelihood of catastrophic failures.



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

As part of the implementation of this RMP Program, key Prevention Program elements were implemented by PPC - Paramount Refinery to manage process safety issues associated with the covered processes.  In addition, common industry standards, policies, and procedures are currently utilized to ensure safe practices are being performed.  

PPC ? Paramount Refinery?s the CalARP Prevention Program 3 elements for flammable substances include:

?    Process Safety Information

?    Process Hazard Analysis

?    Operating Procedures

?    Training

?    Mechanical Integrity

?    Management of Change

?    Pre-Startup Safety Review

?    Compliance Audits

?    Incident Investigation

?    Employee Participation

?    Hot Work Permit

?    Contractors

?    Emergency Planning & Response

Organization Responsibility and Authority

All employees are equally responsible for ensuring the health and safety of themselves and others in the facility.

Management, however, by law and practice, is responsible for ensuring that employees are trained to safely perform their jobs.  Management is also responsible for enforcing safety rules and programs and assuring that employee are following safety requirements.

Managers or supervisors may delegate their authority and responsibility to subordinates; however, they must ensure that the work is performed safely.

Director of Safety and Process Safety Management

The Director of Safety and Process Safety Management has overall authority for the design and implementation of the Injury and Illness Prevention Program, Process Safety Management (PSM), and other related safety programs.  This position is assigned the following duties and responsibilities: 

?    Research, interpret

and comply with applicable regulations and recommended industry and safety guidelines.  Keep management informed of changing regulations and what actions the Company must take to comply.  Keep management apprised of safety practices, problems and compliance attitudes within the company. 

?    Recommend, design and implement training to further safety programs and comply with applicable regulations. Establish and implement communications progress to enhance safety performance. Recommend and establish certification, testing and other methods of measurement to ensure employees have received adequate training concerning the hazards of their jobs. 

?    Provide emergency responder training to Emergency Response Team Members. Provide emergency action training for all Company Employees. 

?    Advise and consult with employees in all levels of the organization regarding safety matters and employee responsibilities to comply with Company safety programs and applicable regulations. Advise and assist line management in analyzing safety hazards and implementing safety programs within their individual areas of responsibility. 

?    Establish enforcement procedures to ensure that safety programs are followed including corrective action and discipline procedures. 

?    Act as liaison between the Company and regulatory agencies such as the California and United States Departments of Occupational Safety and Health and their representatives. 

?    Establish compliance, audit and inspection procedures to ensure that safety programs are being followed and safe working practices are in place. 

?    Make regular and frequent analysis of OSHA 300 log, worker's compensation loss reports and other accident and loss information.  Report findings and recommendations to management and the Safety Committee. 

Managers and Supervisors

Managers and supervisors are responsible for the safety and well being of themselves and their subordinates.  Their responsibilities include the following functions and duties:

?    Providing leadership and example for employees by placing emphasis on safety and enforcing all safety and health programs. 

?    Assure, when a task is assigned, that a review of potential hazards has been completed and that employees are instructed on how to accomplish the job safely. Assure that employees doing the work have adequate safety information. 

?    Assure subordinates have received training and are familiar with hazardous materials with which they come in contact.  Assure that subordinates and themselves have read, understood and implement the precautions contained on the material Safety Data Sheets. 

?    Remain current with regards to company safety programs and applicable regulations, by reading programs and communications, and by attending meetings and presentations hosted by the FPS&S Department. Convene safety meetings to ensure safety information is passed to their subordinates.  Assure that subordinates attend safety meetings and safety training programs. 

?    Assure that units and equipment are maintained in safe operating condition. Correct any unsafe condition immediately.  Report any unsafe condition, which cannot be corrected immediately to upper management and the FPS&S Department.  Notify subordinates, in writing, of any known unsafe condition or faulty equipment and the measures necessary to mitigate the risk. 



FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

Prior to the delivery date of this document, there have been two reportable release at the PPC - Paramount Refinery in the past five (5) years.  For both incidents, no covered substances were released, only combustible byproducts which are not RMP-covered. The first reportable release occurred on August 9th, 2005 at 5:30 PM.  A small intermittent fire was discovered approximately 2 hours after H-805 had been shutdown.  Crude oil was allowed to continue circulating through the heater coils while it cooled.  At 5:25, the snuffing steam to the firebox was turned off in order to prepare the line for blindi

ng by maintenance.  Three to five minutes afterward, a detonation and ensuing fire took place within H-805.  The operator extinguished the flames and ERT was activated.  No injuries occurred due to this incident.  The second reportable release occurred on April 22nd, 2009 at 9:40 PM.  H-101/102 tripped due to high box pressure and the pilot and main burners were tripped.  The Operators reset the burner gases without purging the heater box or measuring the LEL.  Then they attempted to light the H-101 pilots which ignited and detonated.  One operator was taken to the hospital but released later in the evening.  



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM 

Paramount Petroleum is committed to providing a safe and healthful work environment for its employees, the surrounding community and the environment. The prevention of accidents, injuries, fires, emergency releases and other emergency situations is of utmost importance and shall be the first priority for all persons working at the refinery. 

It is anticipated that accidents, injuries and emergency situations may still occur. The Emergency Response Plan (ERP) will provide guidelines for a coordinated emergency management system in the refinery to respond to such situations.  The ERP utilizes proven techniques of the Incident Command System.  When situations dictate, the system will utilize the combined effort from all departments, mutual aid groups and municipal agencies in order to mitigate emergency incidents in a safe, effective and timely manner.  The ERP includes:

?    Emergency Alarm Procedures

?    Evacuation Procedures

?    Safety and Health Considerations

?    Notification Procedures

The ERP is implemented through an Incident Command System (ICS). The ICS has two levels of application.  Small emergencies are responded to by an Emergency Response Team (ERT) consisting of a Shift Incident Commander, Team Leader, and a team of members responsible for coordinating issues related to offsite releases, rescue, and hazardous materials

spills. The Shift Incident Commander also coordinates with the Los Angeles County Fire Department (LACoFD) via telephone. 

For larger emergencies the Director of Safety and Process Safety Management serves as the Incident Commander. An Emergency Management Team (EMT) may also be activated to assist, which is lead by the Vice President of Refining.  Other members of the EMT are members of the refinery senior management. The ERT, which may have initially responded to the emergency, relinquishes incident management to the Director of Safety and Process Safety Management when the latter assumes command and then provides support to the EMT. The Director of Safety and Process Safety Management communicates with the LACoFD and other outside agencies by telephone.  Refinery personnel assigned to ERT or EMT responsibilities receive continued training.  



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Paramount has a tracking system for implementing recommendations that result from Process Hazard Analyses. There is a continuing training and certification program in place.
